Opus45 with cloud code to connect to

community version from start to finish.
In this video, I'm going to show you how
I built and debug NAN workflows with an
unofficial MCP server that works with
NAN V2 and is way more powerful than the
official Naden MCP server that was
released last week. This works for both
NAN cloud and NAN hosted. We're going to
use Docker Cloud Code with an MCP server
and Cloud Skills. And I'm also going to
show you how to update Naden V2 for the
community version. So, let's get into
it. So, Nan recently released this
official MCP server. What's great about
it is it's official. It's remote MCP, so
you can use it on cloud mobile, but it's
very limited. It only has three tools.
Execute workflow, get workflow details,
and search workflows, meaning it's great
for connecting your already working
workflows to external tools like Cloud
Desktop, Lovable, or Cursor. But that's
pretty limited. I want to show you the
unofficial NAND MCB server that I've
been using for months. It's able to
create workflows, edit workflows, look
at executions, and help debug. It's much
better, but it only runs locally. It's a
little more technical. It has completely
change the way I build or debug Naden
workflows. And that is the NAN MCP by CZ
Lancowski. I don't know if I said that
right. I connect this MCP server to an
NAD instance. Then I connected to an IDE
with an agentic coding tool like Cloud
Code so I could build the whole thing
out in a coding environment. It's very
efficient. I'm going to show you how
this whole setup is very powerful for
both NAND cloud users and NAN
self-hosted because in NAND cloud you're
able to use NAND AI to help you build
workflows. You only get about 50 credits
per month. And as great as it is, it
hasn't really been able to push me past
the finish line. And it's not even
available in the self-hosted N instance,
which is where I do most of my work. So,
in my experience, this unofficial MCP
server paired with skills is not only

affordable than what NAN is offering in
its paid cloud subscriptions. It's
better debugging. It's better at problem
